body:
Comment 2: 
That's not a spurious comma. Trailing commas are always allowed in comma-separated list,
and in this example the trailing comma inhibits the insertion of a semicolon at the end,
because a semicolon after a comma is never useful. In contrast, a semicolon after a
string is sometimes useful, like in:

x := "hello, world";

The semicolon insertion rules are not sensitive to parse state, in order to keep the
rules simple and to avoid the truly magical behavior people associate with JavaScript's
semicolon insertion. In particular they are not sensitive to whether the parser is in
the middle of a parenthesized list (in fact, some parenthesized lists can have
semicolons; think about import or var blocks). 

So to avoid the semicolon, insert the comma.
